title: W. Fox McKeithen
text:
Walter Fox McKeithen (September 8, 1946 – July 16, 2005) served five terms as <a href="Secretary%20of%20State%20of%20Louisiana">Secretary of State of Louisiana</a> between 1988 and 2005. He is best known for merging the state's election divisions into one department and for the promotion of historical preservation.
Early life and education.
McKeithen was born in rural <a href="Columbia%2C%20Louisiana">Columbia, Louisiana</a> to <a href="John%20McKeithen">John Julian McKeithen</a> and the former Marjorie Howell Funderburk. According to his tombstone, he was named for two <a href="World%20War%20II">World War II</a> heroes, Walter Bennett and Elmer Fox. He graduated as class president in 1964 from Caldwell Parish High School, the same month in which his father was inaugurated as <a href="Governors%20of%20Louisiana">governor of Louisiana</a>. One of his classmates was future associate justice of the <a href="Louisiana%20Supreme%20Court">Louisiana Supreme Court</a>, <a href="Chet%20D.%20Traylor">Chet D. Traylor</a>. McKeithen attended <a href="Louisiana%20Tech%20University">Louisiana Tech University</a> in <a href="Ruston%2C%20Louisiana">Ruston</a> in <a href="Lincoln%20Parish%2C%20Louisiana">Lincoln Parish</a> to obtain a <a href="bachelor%27s%20degree">bachelor's degree</a> in <a href="history">history</a> and <a href="social%20studies">social studies</a>.
After graduating from Louisiana Tech, McKeithen returned to Caldwell Parish High School, located off <a href="U.S.%20Route%20165">U.S. Route 165</a>, as a civics teacher and <a href="coach%20%28sport%29">coach</a>. He also established three businesses in Caldwell Parish.
Democrat for secretary of state, 1987.
In 1983, McKeithen was elected to the <a href="Louisiana%20House%20of%20Representatives">Louisiana House of Representatives</a> as a <a href="Democratic%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Democrat</a> when the incumbent <a href="Thomas%20%26quot%3BBud%26quot%3B%20Brady">Thomas "Bud" Brady</a> of <a href="La%20Salle%20Parish%2C%20Louisiana">La Salle Parish</a> was shifted into District 22, where he defeated sitting Representative <a href="Richard%20S.%20Thompson">Richard S. Thompson</a> and former legislator <a href="W.L.%20Rambo">W.L. Rambo</a>. 
In 1987, McKeithen was elected secretary of state. In the <a href="nonpartisan%20blanket%20primary">nonpartisan blanket primary</a>, McKeithen led with 462,965 votes (34 percent) to 365,151 (27 percent) for his principal challenger, fellow Democrat Mike Cutshaw, an attorney for the Louisiana Bankers Association. Two <a href="Republican%20Party%20%28United%20States%29">Republican</a> candidates, M. A. "Mike" Tassin and Bobby A. Patrick, shared 13 percent of the vote, and two other Democrats held a combined 19 percent. Three "no party" candidates polled 8 percent. In the <a href="general%20election">general election</a>, McKeithen only narrowly prevailed over Cutshaw, 490,190 (51 percent) to 467,582 (49 percent).
Republican for Secretary of State, 1991.
In the summer of 1989, McKeithen switched to the Republican Party, whose chairman, <a href="William%20%26quot%3BBilly%26quot%3B%20Nungesser">William "Billy" Nungesser</a>, had courted him for a possible 1990 campaign for the <a href="United%20States%20Senate">United States Senate</a> against the Democrat <a href="Bennett%20Johnston">J. Bennett Johnston, Jr.</a> Upon making the party switch, the GOP helped McKeithen pay off $400,000 in campaign debts.
McKeithen announced that he would run for the Senate but dropped such plans when the Republican state convention on January 13, 1990, endorsed <a href="Louisiana%20State%20Senate">State Senator</a> <a href="Ben%20Bagert">Ben Bagert</a> of <a href="New%20Orleans%2C%20Louisiana">New Orleans</a> as the party's preferred candidate. Ultimately, Johnston was reelected in a showdown with another Republican, the maverick <a href="David%20Duke">David Duke</a>, a former figure in the <a href="Ku%20Klux%20Klan">Ku Klux Klan</a>. Bagert left the race two days before the election at the request of national Republican leaders, who endorsed Johnston over Duke. In the 1972 general election, John McKeithen had run as an <a href="Independent%20%28politics%29">Independent</a> for the Senate in an unsuccessful race against Johnston. Fox McKeithen's father and daughter, Marjorie A. McKeithen (born 1965), both opposed the party switch and remained Democrat.
In 1991, McKeithen faced a close contest for reelection as secretary of state. Two Democrats, Mary Chehardy (later a Republican) and Doug Schmidt, challenged him. McKeithen led in the primary, with 629,237 votes (46 percent) to Schmidt's 387,243 (28 percent). Close behind was Chehardy with 357,173 (26 percent). Schmidt, who used the expression "Get the Fox out of the Henhouse", advanced to the general election against McKeithen. In the showdown, McKeithen prevailed by 9,151 votes, a margin similar to <a href="David%20C.%20Treen">David C. Treen</a>'s plurality over Democrat <a href="Louis%20Lambert">Louis Lambert</a> in the 1979 gubernatorial contest. Returns gave McKeithen 827,506 votes to Schmidt's 818,355.
In subsequent elections, McKeithen was often endorsed by Democrats and worked well with members from both parties. His folksy manner meant that he was generally popular with voters despite adopting such unpopular positions as raising the pay of elected state officials. In his last race in 2003, he even carried the endorsement of <a href="organized%20labor">organized labor</a>, which rarely supports Republicans. During January 2004, McKeithen supervised the combining of the former elections department into the secretary of state's office.
A few weeks later, when voting machines were slow to arrive in <a href="New%20Orleans">New Orleans</a> in time for the 2004 elections, he helped to deliver them himself. McKeithen's gravestone in Caldwell Parish lists his principal accomplishments as the restoration of the Old State Capitol in Baton Rouge, the Cotton Museum in <a href="Lake%20Providence%2C%20Louisiana">Lake Providence</a>, the <a href="Delta%20Music%20Museum">Delta Music Museum</a> in <a href="Ferriday%2C%20Louisiana">Ferriday</a>, and the Louisiana Exhibition Building in <a href="Shreveport%2C%20Louisiana">Shreveport</a>.
Death.
After a fall in the garage of his home in Baton Rouge in February 2005, McKeithen was hospitalized with paralysis from the neck down. Trouble struck again, and he re-entered the hospital on June 21 with a serious infection caused from the fall. He resigned as secretary of state on July 15, 2005, and died just a few hours later. He left his state pension to his widow, Yvonne Y. McKeithen.
<a href="Al%20Ater">Alan Ray Ater</a>, a former state representative from <a href="Ferriday%2C%20Louisiana">Ferriday</a> in <a href="Concordia%20Parish">Concordia Parish</a> became the acting secretary of state on McKeithen's death by virtue of having been the first deputy secretary of state. Ater did not seek the position in the <a href="special%20election">special election</a> held on September 30, 2006, to fill the remaining fifteen months of McKeithen's term. Late in 2006, Ater hence turned over the office to Republican state Senator <a href="Jay%20Dardenne">Jay Dardenne</a> (pronounced DAR DEN) of Baton Rouge. Dardenne was declared the winner of the special election after the runner-up candidate, outgoing Democratic state Senator <a href="Francis%20C.%20Heitmeier">Francis C. Heitmeier</a> of <a href="New%20Orleans">New Orleans</a> withdrew from a pending <a href="runoff%20election">runoff election</a>, which would have coincided with the November 7 national general election. In the September 30 election, Dardenne led with 30 percent of the vote. He ran up large margins in the greater Baton Rouge area and finished second in other portions of the state. Heitmeier, who ran best in <a href="Liberalism">liberal</a> and labor areas of the state, trailed with 28 percent.
A third candidate, the <a href="conservatism">conservative</a> former Louisiana Republican State Chairman <a href="Mike%20Francis%20%28politician%29">Mike Francis</a> of <a href="Crowley%2C%20Louisiana">Crowley</a> in <a href="Acadia%20Parish">Acadia Parish</a>, finished with 26 percent of the ballots. He ran well in Acadiana and his native north Louisiana — he is originally from <a href="Jena%2C%20Louisiana">Jena</a> in <a href="La%20Salle%20Parish">La Salle Parish</a> - but trailed badly in Baton Rouge, New Orleans, and the <a href="Florida%20Parishes">Florida Parishes</a>.
Legacy.
In 2006, McKeithen was inducted <a href="Posthumous%20recognition">posthumously</a> into the <a href="Louisiana%20Political%20Museum%20and%20Hall%20of%20Fame">Louisiana Political Museum and Hall of Fame</a> in Winnfield, an honor that his father had procured in 1993, having been among the first thirteen honorees.
